There technical limitations to using cameras that go beyond needs more data. The point clouds created by Lidar data are precise measures, capable of operating at any level of light, and arent hampered by various sources of noise in the surroundings which can cause problems with cameras, such as lights and the like. Further, stereoscopic measurement is essentially inference IE, not a direct measure of distance or timing, but rather on an inferred model based on parallax and relationships. Lidar will always be more accurate than a camera for the simple fact that Lidar is basically a direct measurement, whereas cameras for such cases are an indirect method. You can get fairly accurate with optical cameras, but never nearly so was with Lidar. Stereoscopic and orthological mapping using cameras is processor heavy far moreso than Lidar point clouds, requires more time for data processing, requires actual light to be present, and can get confused by stray light sources. While both have limitations, particularly in rainy or foggy conditions, these limitations are generally the same. The fundamental issue with cameras for FSD isnt one of data, its one of actual technological and physical limitations which are essentially impossible to overcome.

Drivers arent the only cost to a taxi business and do a lot of stuff you take for granted cleaning, arranging servicing and off duty storage etc. Self driving taxis remove the driver cost but then add in a whole bunch of extra costs cleaners, fleet managers etc plus the rather sizable costs of the extra hardware plus software and dev costs. If its viable at all it would only be at huge scale with immense capital costs. With the inevitable low margins its hard to see who that business would appeal to. Lidar works in lowlight conditions, and is more or less a direct measure of distance. Optical methods with cameras perform poorly in low light conditions, and require orthological modeling to determine distance. A lot more can go wrong with optical cameras than Lidar in determining distances due to the far, far more strenuous processing requirements of optical systems that also tend to be far less accurate. Its a bit more apt to say that cameras dont have any particular advantage over Lidar at all aside from cost, and Lidar is a more reliable system overall with fewer fail points to be concerned with. It has some similar limitations in terms of fog and the like, but the biggest difference is that Lidar gives actual distances well, they give actual time between shooting the laser out and reading it, which is innturn calculated to a distance whereas cameras infer distances you have multiple overlapping images that create a 3D model that you can measure in.

replies.text: Apples and Oranges. To me, Uber is no different from what Fiverr or eBay is for freelancing or physical goods. Just a middle man between service provider and consumer. NFLX, on the other hand, has content licensing, and gives a stage to independent studios. Its performance long term depends on what blockbusters new seasons would come out next, e.g. Stranger Things, Squid game, etc.

I think both of these companies are destined to fail. Whatever you do short term is on you, but these arent long term companies. Uber is going to get roasted by Lyft and local services. Netflix lacks the kind of trash TV fodder that Hulu and Paramount have a ton of, and thats essential to hold normies. Nobody gives a shit about The Circle, they want legit Big Brother. Netflix also is the most annoying about account sharing, which nerfs their contents general exposure. Due to the way they are about this my mom, my finance, my sister, and my dad all bring reviews of HuluParamount content to their social circles. Only my mom has access to Netflix, so only her social circle hears about it. Long term apply that concept nationwide. Dont bother with either. There are tens of thousands of other companies, and youre a few years late for the best window of time on these.

I dont think Uber still makes a profit, plus they treat their contractors like garbage. Which has resulted in constant expensive lobbying and litigation. Netflix seems to have been able to figure out how to keep pivoting, such as from a DVD mailing service to digital video streaming service. I dont know how they treat their employees, but havent heard anything negative, so between the two, I would choose Netflix.

Both. thousands more in totalmarket indexbased lowcost funds. Buying individual stocks or sector funds creates unnecessary uncompensated risk I avoid doing so. Index funds are boring, but better for making money. If I wanted to talk about my interesting investments at parties or wanted a new hobby, I might invest 510 of my portfolio in individual stocks. As it is, I own pretty much every publiclytraded company in the world thats interesting enough for me. All of the individual stocks sector funds are being followed by thousands or millions of other investors. Current prices reflect their collective knowledge of future expectations for each one. Im a member of the Triple Nine Society, but Im not smarter than all of them. If I found a stock or sector that looked like a bargain, the most likely explanation would be that the others know something I dont.

Personally like Uber. They have big pictures in mind. Although a broker, they want to be the logistical centerpiece for all transportation, whether goods or people. They are involvedplugged in with googles waymo self driving cars, have their freight operation although was getting some bad feedback for awhile, but seems like they are solving problems internally and externally in that arena and at some point will be handling automated transports, are connected with future and ready for evtols which should greatly impact people and goods transportation. Netflix is a great company, solid stats though and honestly havent researched them enough to know how bright their future looks. I think potential exists if they can expand beyond the standard platform hosting showsvideo game content and get into maybe some of the virtual reality and ai generated content space with users maybe? But my opinion fwiw is that Uber has a lot of room to grow profits as a logistics broker that is forward leaning and visionary.

I was asking which one of these two to but. Not trying to debate index vs individual stocks
But driverless car still need company to dispatch them and Uber has infrastructure

Theres no debate. Not all risks are created equal. The risk of investing in individual stocks is an uncompensated risk. The risk is higher but the expected returns are not. Since theres no benefit to taking such risk, its unnecessary, as I mentioned in my previous reply. Imagine that I offer to give you some money. The amount I give you will depend on what happens when you flip a coin. You can either flip the coin once for 10,000 or you can flip it 100 times for 100 each time. Either way, the expected return is 5,000. The single flip is very risky because theres a 50 chance youll win nothing. Uncompensated risk. The 100 flips are a lot safer because youre pretty likely to get about 5000. BTW, investing in stocks instead of saving in a HYSA, etc. is a compensated risk. Risks are higher but so are expected returns.

Again, not going to debate index vs individual stocks. Each person has their own style and you can also do both. Even for individual stocks, there are growth vs value. You can create your own post to talk about it. No need off talk in this post. I am asking specific question. If you dont know or not interested, thats ok. Just go to other posts

The rise of Uber and Lyft has revealed weaknesses in government oversight, enabling these companies to exploit loopholes and disregard unemployment concerns. By recruiting drivers without stable jobs and paying minimal wages, they disrupt the working class and perpetuate poverty. 

Their profit models prioritize earnings over people, relying on: 

- Withholding driver earnings
- Skimming toll road pennies
- Charging exorbitant rider fees (e.g., Uber's $1.25 and Lyft's $0.85 per transaction) 

Lack of transparency and accountability is alarming, particularly with Lyft's claimed 2.5 million daily riders and 30% profit margin before expenses. This raises questions about operational costs and profit margins, and whether their board properly scrutinizes numbers. 

The use of AI-powered apps instead of human representatives also raises ethical concerns. Furthermore, the push for automated self-driving cars or robotaxis seems more like a marketing ploy to attract uninformed investors. 

Let's consider the airline industry, which has the technical capability to automate but still values human pilots for consumer comfort and trust. Similarly, would you feel comfortable riding a robotaxi on the highway, surrounded by reckless drivers? I'll believe in autonomous transportation when Disney allows software to operate the monorail without a human operator.
